data.title: Error and suggestion highlighting/underlining disappeared after last update
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: OSX Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any file with installed linter extensions: go + golint/gometalinter, javascript + jshint/eslint 
2. Not consistently showing error (red) or suggestion (green) underlining in source code.  Sometimes the session's work just as normal sometimes it stops highlighting. Intelli-sense works consistently.

Started happening yesterday after an update. I deleted VSCode and all extensions and reinstalled. Confident that no settings changed in my workspace/project.

data.title: C++: Searching include paths takes forever if there are large sub-directories
data.body:
I tried using VS Code with a C++ project containing a large non-source directory with thousands of files (profile outputs, logs, etc.). The editor was unable to search the include path even after about an hour. Copying just the source files into a new directory and opening it in VS Code resolved the issue.


- VSCode Version: Code 1.10.2 (8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331, 2017-03-08T13:56:35.908Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|jsx|TwentyChung|0.0.1|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.7|
|vscode-instant-markdown|dbankier|1.1.0|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.3|
|latex|ms-vscode|0.1.3|
|cmake|twxs|0.0.17|
|vim|vscodevim|0.6.5|
|debug|webfreak|0.17.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a large non-source directory (with thousands of profile results, logs, etc.) called "output" under the root directory for the project.
2. Create a main.cpp file which includes header files under a directory called "include" in the root directory for the project.
3. Observe that VS Code gives the green squiggly lines underneath the #include directives, but hovering over it does not produce the light bulb. Instead, there's a pop-up saying "searching include path" and "loading". 
4. Removing the large non-source directory resolves the issue in (3) above.

data.title: Copying code into an Office app (like OneNote or Word) doesn't retain tabbing
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 15055.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a Python file and write code which has indentation - e.g.
```
value = True
if value == True:
    print("Hello, world!")
```
2. Copy to an Office application - e.g. OneNote or Word
Syntax coloring is retained, but indentation is lost

data.title: [Question] [Help-Wanted] How to set intellisense for Angular.Js in VSCode?
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: VSCode 1.10.2 and 1.11.0-insiders
- OS Version: Windows 10

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

I've tried several places, but none that worked for me. Maybe because of the process being old, and there is a more current way.

I have already followed these tutorials, but none worked for me.

- It seems to be old compared to others -> https://johnpapa.net/intellisense-witha-visual-studio-code/
-  Very similiar to my question -> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/38930984/how-to-set-intellisense-for-angular-js-and-javascript-in-visual-studio-code-with
-  It seems to be more current -> http://www.bardev.com/2016/06/21/using-visual-studio-code-ceate-angularjs-applications/
-> https://weblogs.asp.net/lduveau/getting-angular-intellisense-in-visual-studio-code


So can anyone help?


Is it possible to configure global or only by project? If you have how to do globally, how to do it?

Sorry, if it is not the right place (but I have already looked for several places), but on the site itself I could have a tutorial explaining this (It's a tip).


Thank you very much.

**Update:** Currently I'm using AngularJS 1.5.x. I do not know if it is possible to configure according to the version of angularjs.

data.title: Support terminal shell args as string
data.body: Fixes #19078

data.title: Support UTF-16 w/o BOM
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Create a UTF-16 file without a BOM at the beginning of the file
2. Attempt to open it inside VS Code, it will not open because it is detected to be "binary"

Both Sublime Text and Atom can open UTF-16 files without a byte order marker, but VS Code cannot. Sublime Text does it perfectly, while Atom needs some coaxing to get it render the file as UTF-16LE (it initially identifies it as UTF-8). However, VS Code does not provide any options changing the encoding that a file is loaded with.

For people developing CSV files, UTF-16LE w/o BOM is a format that is supported widely for opening in Excel. Without support for this encoding in VS Code, these CSV files cannot be opened.

data.title: Move command palette below editor tabs
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

The command palette overlaps the tabs of all your open files. This is particularly problematic when you are using the command palette to open a file and you want to reference your tabs that are currently open. Use-case: I am working on `some-really-unique-filename.component.js` and open the command palette to go to `some-really-unique-filename.style.css`- but the command palette overlays all the tabs and I cant see the tab for `some-really-unique-filename.component.js` to reference it while opening its corresponding CSS file.

![screen shot 2017-03-13 at 12 50 51 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10407384/23872666/674813ec-07ec-11e7-8002-a72507241432.png)

_**Suggested Behavior:**_ Open the command palette right underneath the tabs.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have many files open at once.
2. Open the command palette and see how it overlaps the tabs.

data.title: Feature request: Setting to change workspaceStorage location
data.body: Our C++ extension can generate several GB of per-workspace data (and theoretically so could other extensions). We want some sort of workspaceStorage setting so users can change the location to a drive with more storage space. The default on Windows is AppData\Roaming\Code\User\workspaceStorage. Our extension could provide this setting ourselves, but it seems like it should belong to VS code so that everyone using the workspaceStorage can benefit.

data.title: Add backwards search to preferences view
data.body: This patch allows shift+f to search backwards in the preferences search.

data.title: Entering a path to a valid file in the "Go To File" (cmd-P) popup should immediately resolve to a file
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.10.2 (1.10.2)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a large project
2. Open the "Go To File" popup (cmd-P on Mac)
3. Enter a relative path to a file in the project

vscode seems to do some sort of query at this point and takes a while to resolve something, even though it could just immediately check to see if that file exists.

data.title: [Feature Request] Multiple Active Search
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 14393

When I go into a code base, particularly one that is new to me, I might have good luck finding a symbol by doing a global project search (Ctrl+Shift+F to start).  Then I'll find what I'm looking for, but a comment or another symbol will prompt me to look further. 

The language services do pretty well sometimes when handling this situation, but other languages don't necessarily have the same level of support.  So I'm prompted (practically speaking) to open another search.  The trouble here is that it makes my first search go away -- specifically, I lose the state.  I lose which item I last opened, I lose the files that I've collapsed or expanded, etc.

Can we stash Search Results into the pane so we can pull them back up and continue navigating?

data.title: Fix Markdown TOC Provider for Invalid References
data.body:
Fixes #22494

**Bug**
References without a definition can cause the markdown table of contents provider to break

**Fix**
Pass in an empty environment to markdown-it `parse` to prevent the null dereference on invalid links. Also picks up new markdown it version and fixes a potential case where `currentDocument` is undefined

data.title: [loc][Query][VSCode] Please clarify context for "node.protocol.auto.description"
data.body:
Hi, we have a question from our translator. Can you help please? Thanks!

**Source:**
try to detect the best protocol automatically

**File Name:**
package.nls.resx

**Resource ID:**
".resx", 0; "node.protocol.auto.description"

**Query:**
Context required. Does "try" refer to a program/process/etc. or to the user? Thanks!
